Project Description  The proposed technical assistance (TA) loan is designed to 
facilitate  knowledge  and  information  acquisition,  and 
institutional  support  mechanisms,  with  the  overall  aim  of 
expanding  employment  opportunities,  and  enhancing  the 
competitiveness  of  micro-  and  small  enterprises  (MSEs)  in 
rural areas on a sustainable basis. 
   
Rationale  Pakistan depends substantially on agriculture and other rural 
activities to provide livelihoods for the majority of its population. 
For Pakistan to meet its goal of reducing poverty by half by 
2015, and also to reduce rapid rural-urban migration, nonfarm 
economic  opportunities  in  rural  areas  need  to  expand.  The 
country has around 150,000 small businesses and more than 
three million microenterprises. The informal economy is largely 
unregulated and faces crucial resource constraints, particularly 
finance,  skills,  new  technology  and  knowledge,  and 
management.  Access  to  finance,  improved  technology,  and 
potential new markets and average standards of quality and 
product  uniformity  are  especially  low.  The  business 
environment  in  the  informal  sector  is  often  difficult  and 
occasionally  chaotic.  Since  more  than  90%  of  Pakistan’s 
businesses  are  in  this  sector,  there  is  enormous  need  to 
increase factor productivity. Despite some success, however, 
many initiatives have been constrained by a variety of social, 
institutional, and political factors. What is required in view of 
the problems mentioned is an innovative approach that works 
outside conventional institutions, and draws on lessons learned 
and  international  best  practices,  to  improve  the 
competitiveness of rural and peri-urban MSEs.

iv 
Impact and Outcome  The designed impact of the TA loan is to create and diversify  
job  and  income-earning  opportunities  in  the  rural  areas 
especially for the landless, wage earners, and women. The 
intended outcome is to develop market facilitation processes 
by  identifying  and  filling  market  gaps  within  selected 
subsectors in rural and peri-urban areas, and strengthening the 
competitiveness of the target groups. Steps will be taken to 
design innovative institutional arrangements and assess the 
feasibility of establishing a not-for-profit company to catalyze 
business development services and introduce best practices in 
enhancing social and environmental processes in support of 
the growth of rural businesses. 
   
Cost Estimates  The estimated project cost is $6.5 million equivalent, including 
physical and price contingencies, duties and taxes, and interest 
and  service  charges  during  implementation.  The  foreign 
exchange cost is estimated at $2.6 million, or 40% of the total 
cost.  The  local  currency  cost  is  estimated  at  $3.9  million 
equivalent, 60% of the total cost. Local currency costs include 
an estimated $155,000 equivalent in duties and taxes to be 
paid by the Government of Pakistan.

These developments will be a consequence of addressing the

Risks and Assumptions  The  project  design  makes  a  number  of  assumptions  with 
  associated risks. It is assumed that the Government remains 
  strongly committed to improving the market opportunities and 
  competitiveness of rural enterprises, especially those that now 
  lack  access  to  markets.  So  far  the  Government  has 
  demonstrated  strong  ownership  and  commitment  through  a 
  focus on addressing constraints in market access in the rural 
  areas. It is recognized that the project design will require a 
  knowledge-intensive  approach,  with  a  high  degree  of 
  responsiveness to emerging market opportunities. In addition, 
there is a need to work with a number of institutions both within 
and outside the government. Extensive consultations with all 
stakeholders,  including  the  private  sector,  and  high-level 
government support if not realized could delay the Project and 
limit  understanding  and  development  of  the  appropriate 
institutional processes required to support the competitiveness 
of rural enterprises. This risk is addressed through the creation 
of  a  high-level  steering  committee  with  adequate 
representation from the Government and the private sector. In 
addition,   the Project provides flexibility in engaging the private 
sector  and  other  stakeholders in all undertakings, and on-
time availability of a  range of  consultants  with   demonstrated 
  technical knowledge and international experience to analyze 
the subsectors and design initiatives that respond to market 
opportunities  in  the  rural  areas.  The  need  to  stimulate 
improvements  in  design  and  quality  and  to  ensure  social 
compliance with labor laws, etc., among the rural enterprises is 
addressed  through  comprehensive  subsector  analysis, 
followed  by  carefully  designed  pilot  interventions  with 
appropriate  social  safeguards  and  processes  and  private 
sector linkages. The results of this subsector analysis and the 
pilot interventions will in turn inform the business plan to be 
prepared for the establishment of an institution that will support 
the  development  of  business  opportunities  for  rural 
entrepreneurs.  This  sequencing  of  implementation  gives 
adequate  focus  to  preparing  relevant  area-  and  product-
specific strategies for promoting business development, and 
minimizes the risk that the institution that is set up might fail to 
be socially responsive, sustainable, and relevant to the needs 
of the underserved rural entrepreneurs.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
technical assistance (TA) loan to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for the Rural Enterprise 
Modernization Project. The design and monitoring framework is presented in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  In South Asia as a whole, the nonfarm economy accounts for roughly 25% of rural 
employment and 29% of rural incomes.1 Seasonal trading, agro-processing, manufacturing, and 
service activities enhance rural livelihoods, support a growing agriculture, and supply consumer 
goods and services. Nonfarm activity offers important economic opportunities for the rural poor in 
areas where landlessness is high. Pakistan’s population is 68% rural and agriculture accounts for 
almost 45% of total employment. Outside the agriculture sector, 46% of the rural poor (and 22% of 
the rural population) are nonfarm households that do not share directly in incomes derived from 
agricultural crop production. Despite declining rural poverty in the 1970s and 1980s, poverty 
remained high in the 1990s. Real growth in agriculture declined to an average annual rate of 2.4% 
with sharp year-to-year fluctuations from 1990 to 2002, compared with the overall rate of 3.5% 
achieved from 1960 onward. The yields of the major crops have largely stagnated in the past 
decade. The percentage of the rural poor living below the poverty line was essentially unchanged 
between 1990 (36.9%) and 1999 (35.9%), and even rose to 38.9% in 2002, a drought year. If 
Pakistan is to meet its goal of reducing poverty by half by 2015, rural economic opportunities must 
expand in agriculture and the nonfarm sector. In the absence of a change in the structure of rural 
incomes and employment, growth in traditional crop agriculture and associated growth linkages 
may not be adequate to substantially raise the incomes of the rural nonfarm poor households. 
Strategies to promote rural nonfarm income opportunities are therefore necessary to make an 
impact on rural poverty in Pakistan.  
 
3.  In many areas of rural development, Pakistan lags behind its Asian neighbors with fewer 
natural resources. Drought and the poor performance of crops and livestock often force rural 
people to migrate at least temporarily to the cities. This situation is exacerbated by the system 
of landholding, which is characterized by a high degree of land concentration by ownership and 
by a high incidence of sharecropping tenure in the two most populous provinces of Sindh and 
Punjab. Cities like Karachi with a population of around 14 million are increasingly ill-equipped to 
handle the concomitant problems of overcrowding and pressure on the urban infrastructure and 
environment. The urban population grew from 24 million in 1981 to 53 million in 2005. Hence, 
there is a pressing need (also found in other Asian countries) to seek nontraditional work 
opportunities in rural areas. Efforts must therefore be made to diversify the rural economy in 
nonfarm sectors such as services, small-scale manufacturing, and value-added agricultural 
processing. The proposed TA loan targets rural and peri-urban enterprises that have potential 
for labor-intensive growth if provided with synergistic support by a range of private sector, 
nongovernment, and public sector partners.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Problems Faced by Rural Enterprises 
 
4.  Pakistan  has  around  150,000  small  businesses  and  more  than  3  million 
microenterprises, which together compose more than 90% of the country’s total businesses. 
Many of the micro- and small enterprises (MSEs) are in rural areas and depend heavily on 
agricultural raw materials and poorly skilled nonfarm labor. Rural businesses face difficulty in 
accessing a range of essential financial and business development services (BDS).2 Access to 
finance and improved technology and average standards of quality and product uniformity are 
especially low. More importantly, challenges are posed by (i) the generally low level of literacy, 
particularly among women; (ii) poor business management practices; and (iii) reluctance or 
limited  capacity  to  adopt  more  modern  technology  and  practices,  and  to  take  on  new 
commercial  risks.  Entrenched  linguistic  and  ethnic  differences  provide  further  obstacles  to 
investment in nonfarm activities that cross provincial or tribal boundaries. 
 
5.  The MSE business environment is influenced, by, among others, infrastructure, social 
relationships,  energy  costs  and  reliability,  and  increasing  competition  from  modern  urban 
businesses and imports, which pose tough challenges in niche and mass markets. These 
factors translate into underdeveloped rural nonfarm enterprises and cottage industries, and loss 
of opportunities for employment growth and added market value. The status of selected rural 
industries is presented in Appendix 2. 
 
  2.  Policy Initiatives and Rural Finance Programs in Pakistan  
 
6.  Private businesses, including MSEs and small and medium enterprises (SMEs), are the 
primary  target  groups  of  the  Government’s  program  to  promote  growth  through  economic 
diversification. This is reflected in the Government’s Medium-Term Development Framework, 
which aims, among others, to facilitate the development of human capital and the private sector 
as engines of economic growth. Finalized in July 2005, the framework recognizes the need to 
increase  factor  productivity  through  technology-led  human  resource  development  that  builds 
capacity for innovation and leverages local knowledge. This vision will require a combined effort to 
add to the human resource base via a range of interventions, including bringing more women into 
the labor force, increasing skill levels, and combining these skills with better infrastructure and 
technology. With this broad strategy in mind, Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Country Strategy 
and  Program  (2006–2008)  notes  ADB’s  role  in  promoting  the  private  sector  as  a  driver  of 
investment, growth, and employment generation. The proposed TA loan is the third innovative 
ADB effort to support the Government’s objective of private sector–led enterprise development.3 
 
7.  Formal  financial  sector  lending  to  rural  MSEs/SMEs  is  very  low,  but  this  is  being 
addressed by the Government and is expected to improve gradually. Data relating specifically to 
rural MSEs are limited, but in the SME sector only about 5% of some 50,000 enterprises with

8.  Serious impetus for developing microfinance—which presents the main medium-term 
option for many MSEs to access financial services—came in the late 1990s as the sector came 
to be regarded as an important strategic instrument for addressing rising poverty in Pakistan. 
Comprehensive policy regulations, including the Microfinance Ordinance 2002, were formulated. 
The credit and savings program of the Aga Khan Rural Support Program (AKRSP) evolved into 
the First Microfinance Bank, and led to the subsequent establishment of the Khushali Bank 
under  the  ADB-financed  Microfinance  Sector  Development  Program.4 With  an  increase  in 
borrowers from 100,000 in 1999 to more than 400,000 in 2004, and a gross loan portfolio of 
PRs4.5 billion, the microfinance sector has grown rapidly in recent years. Although less than 6% 
of the market is now being served, it is projected that by 2009 the number of active borrowers 
will rise to 2.9 million.5 
 
3.  Small Nonfarm Enterprise Development in Rural Asia 
 
9.  In Asia as a whole, rural nonfarm growth has been fastest in countries having a dynamic 
agriculture, rapid urban-industrial growth, requisite managerial and labor skills, ready markets 
for inputs (including financing) and outputs, and good basic infrastructure (roads, power, and 
communications). A central feature of Asia’s rural nonfarm growth is that it has been led almost 
entirely by the market and the private sector. Public sector efforts to directly organize rural 
industry and business have generally not succeeded on a broad scale. 
 
10.  Besides ADB and AKRSP, support for private enterprise development in Pakistan has 
been provided by the World Bank, bilateral donors including the Swiss Agency for Development 
and Cooperation, and a range of nongovernment organizations (NGOs) (Appendix 3). More 
broadly, rural MSE/SME efforts in the Asian region have included both public and private sector 
(profit oriented) initiatives. In 1998–2000, the Committee of Donor Agencies for Small Enterprise 
Development—in  which  ADB  participated—organized  a  series  of  international  and  regional 
conferences that led to an emerging consensus on principles for donor interventions in BDS.6 The 
BDS market development paradigm is based on the principle that achieving economic and social 
goals is possible only by relying on private sector actors to provide a diverse array of services. 
Relying  on  the  private  sector  requires  understanding  how  BDS  providers  can  be  financially 
self-sustaining. The design of the TA loan reflects the experience gained in the major rural

a.  Mechanisms for Program Delivery/Institutional Models 
 
11.  The following section provides a summary of program delivery mechanisms for providing 
business development services to MSEs/SMEs. 
 
(i)  Under SMESDP, ADB has actively engaged the Small and Medium Enterprise 
Development Authority (SMEDA) in reorienting its BDS approach. As a result, 
SMEDA has started to move away from direct intervention in SME training and 
preparation of business plans to a more facilitative role. Additional impetus to 
these efforts will come from the Business Support Fund (BSF), which upon its 
establishment will improve market-based SME access to BDS. Despite adequate 
planning and consultations during the preparation of SMESDP, the establishment 
of  BSF  has  taken  more  time  than  expected.  From  experience,  innovative 
initiatives  involving  a  new  and  diverse  set  of  stakeholders  require  adequate 
planning and support for public sector consensus building to ensure that the 
initiative can take off. 
(i)  Public  funds  should  be  used  for  developing  markets  rather  than  individual 
businesses, so that more target commercial stakeholders can benefit. Publicly 
funded programs should therefore focus on market growth and address market 
gaps and failures to the advantage of the target business groups. The programs 
should not directly deliver services to small enterprises, since that would be cost-
ineffective and would limit outreach, would not be sustainable in the long run, and 
would lead to supply-led rather than demand-driven services. 
(ii)  Direct interactions between publicly funded programs and small businesses are 
based on an unequal relationship if the latter cannot hold the former accountable 
for the quality and range of the services provided. These interactions should be 
mutually accountable, businesslike, and transaction-based. 
(iii)  Businesses should be established in the private sector by entrepreneurs taking 
the  lead,  not  publicly  funded  organizations,  since  the  latter  would  displace 
competition and private sector initiative. More importantly, the financial discipline 
and vigilance that comes with investing equity or taking recourse to debt augurs 
well for the profitability of a business and the careful calculation of risks that the 
entrepreneur must make. 
(iv)  Businesses  established  with  cost-free  donor  money  and  housed  in  social 
development organizations are undermined by inherent conflicts between the 
social  development  goals  of  the  organization  and  the  profit  motive  and 
commercial competitiveness of the business. 
 
b.  Focus of Interventions 
 
12.  A suggested menu of approaches to target focused interventions for MSE development 
on a competitive basis are listed in the following section. 
 
(i)  MSE development must be considered in the context of the commercial and 
social  milieu,  not  in  isolation  from  it.  Otherwise,  efforts  will  not  address  the 
fundamental constraints of disconnection from demand, innovation, knowledge, 
technology, competition, and efficiencies present in the formal sector. The latter

5
is  an  invaluable  repository  of  technical  and  managerial  skills  for  small 
businesses, which can in turn enable large businesses to minimize overhead 
costs through outsourcing.  
(ii)  Programmatic interventions of publicly funded development programs should be 
time-bound, i.e., designed with exit strategies in mind so that the sustainability of 
impact is considered right from the start of the intervention. 
(iii)  The  problem  for  small  businesses  is  not  just  marketing  and  design,  but 
understanding  whether  producing  what  consumers  want  is  financially  and 
technically feasible. Frequently, too many resources are spent trying to market 
existing products, rather than understanding what different consumer segments 
want, and whether the target business groups have the potential capacity to meet 
those demands. 
(iv)  Export  markets  are  very  competitive  and  difficult  to  tap.  The  required 
standardization, high volume, and quality at competitive prices are not easily 
accomplished by rural enterprises. 
(v)  Product innovation initiatives should be (a) based on holistic market research 
about what will be required at the production, marketing, sales, and management 
levels; and (b) guided by whether it is within the existing or potential capacity of the 
target business groups to compete profitably. All of these should be driven by the 
kinds of products different consumers want. 
(vi)  Direct subsidies should be avoided. Where deemed necessary, they must have 
clear objectives, be time-bound, with terms and expectations clearly understood by 
the recipients. Otherwise, it is difficult to wean businesses away from free services, 
dependency is created, and the commercial market for BDS is distorted. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE LOAN 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The overall objective of the TA loan is to create and diversify job and income-earning 
opportunities in the Project area, particularly for the landless, wage earners, and women. The 
purpose is to develop market facilitation processes by identifying and strengthening market gaps 
within selected subsectors Project area, and enhance the competitiveness of the target groups by 
facilitating access to a range of BDS, including appropriate technologies and financial capital. The 
TA loan  will  help  analyze  opportunities  in  designing  innovative institutional arrangements and 
assess the feasibility of establishing a not-for-profit company that would serve as a focal point for 
initiatives to support the development and growth of rural businesses. Initiatives under the TA loan 
will be aimed at enhancing the competitiveness of small businesses by enabling them to improve 
the  quality,  standardization,  volume,  and  value  addition  of  their  products,  and  to  serve  more 
effectively a larger consumer base and niche markets. Rural enterprise modernization will also entail 
increasing awareness among MSEs about BDS and related social and environmental safeguards, 
and  identifying  and  enabling  access  by  rural  businesses  to  a  range  of  appropriate  BDS, 
technologies, and financing, all customized to match rural MSE absorptive capacity and business 
potential. The TA loan embodies a three-pronged strategy: (i) identify key opportunities for local, 
nonfarm rural growth; (ii) focus on subsector-specific supply chains and constraints on expansion; 
and (iii) build diverse, flexible coalitions among partners that have interest in achieving results. 
 
B.  Outputs 
14.  The TA loan will (i) fill major gaps in information and analysis on rural nonfarm MSEs

3.  Rural Enterprise Modernization Company 
 
27.  International experience indicates that opportunities in rural competitiveness can be 
stimulated by access to a range of BDS services. These services facilitate acquisition of skills, 
know-how, expertise, and market understanding by the rural MSEs. The Pakistani market is 
characterized by a generally low usage of BDS in the rural areas, which adversely affects the 
sector’s competitiveness and its potential contribution to the economy of Pakistan. To fill this 
vacuum in the rural areas, there is a strong rationale for supporting institutional processes that 
can  strengthen  private  business  competitiveness  in  rural  areas  to  achieve  growth  in 
employment  and  income,  particularly  among  enterprising  low-income  and  disadvantaged 
individuals and groups. Given the information gaps confronting rural markets in the nonfarm 
sector,  preparatory  work  is  designed  to  better  understand  market  opportunities  for  the 
underserved MSEs. Work carried out to identify potential subsectors, consolidate required data, 
and  draw  up  the  framework  for  the  pilot  projects  will  provide  the  basis  for  analyzing  the 
institutional processes required to stimulate competitive business development opportunities in 
the rural areas and to establish the proposed REMC.  
 
28.  The MDP team will also analyze alternative institutional support processes to document 
options available to the Government to strengthen private business competitiveness in rural 
areas to achieve sustained growth of employment and incomes. It is expected that within 18

decision  on  the  establishment  of  the  REMC,  in  case  its  feasibility  is  established  and  the

C.  Special Features 
 
1.   Complementarity with Other Development Projects 
 
34.  The  TA  loan  is  a  unique  initiative  to  strengthen  rural  nonfarm  enterprises  and  will 
complement the interventions of SMESDP and ADP. The TA loan will focus on investigating and 
developing the latent potential of business groups in the rural nonfarm economy. This focus 
differs from the urban-based approach of SMESDP and the agribusiness focus of the ADP. At 
the same time, coordination and networking with SMESDP and ADP will ensure experience 
sharing and synergy. Coordination with rural support programs and NGOs will enable the REMC 
to  facilitate  access  to  enterprising  communities  and  linkages  with  social  interventions  in 
education,  health,  and  small  infrastructure  projects.  Collaboration  with  these  partners  will 
enhance the leverage for policy advocacy on behalf of the rural poor. 
 
35.  Employment Practices. Efforts will be made to contribute to the promotion of socially 
responsive initiatives through pilot interventions. Capacity building and awareness measures, 
among  others,  will  be  included  to  ensure  that  relevant  International  Labour  Organization 
conventions  (182  and  138)  are  not  breached.  Experiences  within  Pakistan,  particularly  in 
Sialkot, provide useful insights. International companies sourcing sports goods from Pakistan 
have appointed NGOs and other groups to monitor labor practices in MSEs making soccer balls 
in Pakistan. There is an increased effort on a global level to strengthen internal monitoring 
efforts and ensure that suppliers comply with local laws and company guidelines relating to the 
nonuse of child labor. Some of these companies use NGOs, while others use not-for-profit 
organizations that provide auditing and monitoring services to ensure that their company codes 
are implemented.

capacity in the rural areas. A particular focus will be to support grassroots enterprise experience to

coopt other members on a need basis. The steering committee will meet as often as required 
but at least once every 6 months. It will provide strategic and policy guidance to the MDP team 
and REMC, approve the annual work plans and budgets, monitor and evaluate performance, 
and facilitate intersectoral and interdepartmental coordination. 
 
2.  Implementation Period 
 
44.  The TA loan will be utilized over 3 years. This will allow time to set up a functional rural 
enterprise modernization cell at SMEDA, and subsequently REMC (if found feasible), undertake 
the comprehensive subsector analyses, and initiate work on core pilot project interventions, 
which  are  critical  for  designing  follow-on  interventions  to  promote  market-led  growth.  The 
establishment of an appropriate institution to steer the process of rural enterprise modernization 
will require extensive stakeholder consultations within the Government and with private sector 
organizations. More importantly, sufficient time is required for a careful assessment of relevant 
initiatives in the region and their applicability to Pakistan. A comprehensive capacity-building 
program and the task of designing the pilot projects will allow the staff at the rural enterprise 
modernization cell to gain hands-on experience in implementing a facilitative program, so that 
the  lessons  can  feed  into  institutional  development  approaches  required  for  a  scaled-up 
program that ADB may later support. The MDP office and basic support staff required for the 
rural enterprise modernization cell will be assigned within 1 month of loan effectiveness, and the 
first four pilot projects (including two focused on women) will be developed within 12 months of

15
loan effectiveness. If its establishment is approved, the REMC will be incorporated within 24 
months of loan effectiveness (Appendix 7). 
 
  3.  Procurement 
 
45.  Goods and services to be financed from the proceeds of the ADB loan will be procured in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. Vehicles, equipment, and materials will be 
procured through international competitive bidding if they cost more than $500,000 equivalent, or 
by international shopping if they cost from $100,000 to $500,000 equivalent. If there are several 
local suppliers with satisfactory service facilities, equipment or materials valued at less than 
$100,000  equivalent  may  be  procured  through  local  competitive  bidding.  The  equipment  or 
materials may be directly purchased if they cost less than $50,000 (Appendix 8).    
 
4.  Consulting Services and Technical Assistance 
46.  Consulting services are required for technical inputs and core project management. The 
TA loan will provide 108 person-months of international consulting services and 218 person-
months of domestic consulting services (Appendix 9). All consultants will be recruited according 
to ADB’s Guidelines for the Use of Consultants and other arrangements acceptable to ADB for 
selection  and  engagement  of  domestic  consultants.  Except  for  the  international  team 
leader/senior markets development specialist, who will be recruited as an individual consultant, 
the core international and local consultants will be recruited through a firm, with the use of the 
quality  and  cost–based  system.  In  addition  to  the  core  consulting  services,  NGOs  will  be 
engaged  individually  as  needed  to  provide  inputs  in  the  market  surveys,  organize  small 
entrepreneurs,  and  organize  training  workshops  and  focus  group  discussions  on  potential 
opportunities  in  selected  locations.  Of  the  consultant  services  total  indicated  above, 
approximately 72 person-months of international services and 170 person-months of domestic 
services will be available in a flexible resource pool to be tapped when needs arise (e.g., market 
researchers, subject matter and sector specialists, designers, ICT experts, process engineers, 
and poverty, gender, and environment specialists).  
 
  5.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
47.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998) was explained to and discussed with the Islamic 
Republic of Pakistan and Ministry of Industries, Production, and Special Initiatives. Consistent 
with its commitment to good governance, accountability and transparency, ADB reserves the 
right to investigate, directly or through its agents, any alleged corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or 
coercive practices relating to the Project. To support these efforts, relevant provisions of ADB’s 
Anticorruption Policy are included in the loan regulations and the bidding documents for the 
Project. In particular, all contracts financed by ADB in connection with the Project shall include 
provisions specifying the right of ADB to audit and examine the records and accounts of the 
Executing Agency and all contractors, suppliers, consultants, and other service providers as 
they relate to the Project. 
 
6.  Disbursement Arrangements 
48.  The loan proceeds will be disbursed in accordance with the provisions of ADB’s Loan 
Disbursement Handbook. To expedite disbursements, an imprest account will be established 
and maintained by SMEDA at the National Bank of Pakistan for the implementation of the MDP 
component. After REMC is established and enters into a project agreement with ADB, REMC 
will  set  up  an  imprest  account  for  its  operation.  The  imprest  account  will  be  established, 
managed, replenished, and liquidated in accordance with ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook,

16 
and  detailed  arrangements  agreed  to  by  the  Government  and  ADB.  The  statement  of 
expenditure (SOE) procedure will be used in reimbursing eligible expenditures and liquidating 
the imprest account for any individual payment transaction of up to $100,000 equivalent. The 
initial  advance  to  the  imprest  account  will  be  based  on  approved  contracts  and  planned 
expenditures for the first 6 months of the Project. However, total advances at any time are not to 
exceed  estimated  expenditures  for  the  next  6  months  or  10%  of  the  total  loan  amount, 
whichever is less.  
 
7.  Accounting, Auditing, and Reporting 
49.  In each year of implementation, the EA will provide ADB with concise quarterly reports 
detailing  the  physical  and  financial  progress  of  activities  against  agreed  targets  and 
summarizing the results of benefit monitoring and evaluation. SMEDA and REMC (upon its 
establishment) will maintain separate records and accounts adequate to identify the goods and 
services financed from loan proceeds, the expenditures incurred, and the use of local funds. 
Accounts will be established and maintained in accordance with generally accepted accounting 
principles and following the guidelines and procedures of the Ministry of Finance. Consolidated 
project accounts and related financial statements will be compiled and audited annually by 
independent external auditors acceptable to ADB. The audited accounts, audit report, and 
related financial statements will be submitted to ADB in English not later than 6 months after the 
fiscal year to which they relate and should include an audit with a separate opinion on the use of 
the  imprest  account  and  SOE  procedure.  SMEDA  has  financial  controls  in  place  and  the 
accounts are subject to government procedures and regular audit by independent auditors 
appointed by the SMEDA board. 
 
8.  Project Performance Monitoring and Evaluation 
50.  MoIPSI will ensure that SMEDA takes steps to set up a project performance management 
system (PPMS) as agreed with ADB, within 6 months of the effective date, cause it to be operated 
throughout the project period, and transfer it to REMC upon its establishment. Under the PPMS, 
MoIPSI shall also periodically review the Project to assess and evaluate its scope, implementation 
arrangements,  benefit  monitoring,  progress,  and  achievements.  Within  3  months  of  project 
completion,  MoIPSI  shall  submit  to  ADB  a  project  completion  report  providing  a  detailed 
evaluation of the progress implementation, costs, consultants’ performance, social and economic 
impact, and other details requested by ADB. 
 
51.  Within 6 months of the effective date, the Government shall ensure that the gender 
strategy described in the summary poverty reduction and social strategy plan (Appendix 10) has 
been refined and that a gender-disaggregated PPMS has been established as agreed with 
ADB.  Within  9  months  of  the  effective  date,  the  detailed  plan  for  gender-disaggregated 
performance monitoring for ADB’s review and concurrence shall be finalized and the baseline 
survey for selected subsectors shall be completed.    
 
52.  The PPMS will be in line with the performance measurement framework to be developed 
in detail for all three components. In component 1, the performance measurement framework 
will include a detailed set of criteria for the selection of subsectors, the design of the studies and 
data collection, and the evaluation of the quality of the studies and data and their usefulness to 
the pilot projects and REMC. Component 2 will involve three activities: (i) detailed design of the 
selection  of  pilot  projects  and  their  rationale;  (ii)  monthly  or  quarterly  monitoring  of 
implementation, using monitoring indicators to link inputs to output; and (iii) for each pilot 
project,  evaluation  of  the  outcome  (output-to-outcome  relationships)  against  expectations,

17
including successes and failures and the reasons for them (market size, product quality, types 
of  services  and  products,  competitiveness,  penetration  or  reach  in  domestic  and  foreign 
markets, socioeconomic profile of producers and consumers, etc). Component 3 will require (i) 
regular monitoring (financial and administrative) using performance indicators, (ii) evaluation of 
outreach activities based on the lessons from the pilot projects, and (iii) assessment of the 
impact of the pilot projects and outreach programs. Impact assessment would focus on the 
outcomes of the pilot projects and REMC outreach. 
 
9.   Project Review 
 
53.  During the period of the TA loan, ADB will carry out an annual review to (i) determine if 
all implementation arrangements are in place and are appropriate and effective, (ii) assess the 
outcome of the capacity-building activities and training programs, (iii) assess the progress of 
business and market development at the village and local levels, and (iv) recommend changes 
in implementation arrangements, as required. 
 
54.  It is recognized that the Project will demand close monitoring and supervision so that the 
necessary corrective actions can be determined at an early stage. Quarterly progress review 
missions are therefore necessary in the first year of implementation. Thereafter, missions will 
review the Project every 6 months. Adequate support from the Pakistan Resident Mission 
(PRM), regularly provided, will be critical to ensure effective supervision by ADB.18 A midterm 
review mission is planned 18 months after the effective date to discuss with the Government the 
feasibility  of  establishing  REMC  and  alternate  strategies  and  options  for  supporting  the 
development of BDS in the rural areas. 
 
55.  Periodic stakeholder workshops will be held to discuss and document experiences. 
Eighteen months after the inception of the TA loan, an independent assessment of the project 
will  be  undertaken19 by  consultants  with  experience  in  rural  enterprise  development.  The 
objective will be to draw lessons and operational insights from the pilot projects, to identify best 
practices and initiatives, and to use the insights and knowledge gained to inform the subsequent 
agenda and programs of REMC. The findings of stakeholder workshops and the independent 
assessment  will  be  crucial  for  the  development  of  follow-on  initiatives  to  scale  up  the 
interventions across a wider geographic and sectoral range. 
 
IV.  BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
 
A.   Economic Impact and Benefits 
 
56.  In essence, the TA loan is a pilot exercise that will assess constraints and opportunities 
in  the  rural  nonfarm  sector  and  develop  an  institutional  framework  to  facilitate  enterprise 
development and a more modern approach to rural business through better design, technology, 
and marketing. The direct long-term benefits will flow from increased nonfarm employment and 
income-earning opportunities in the rural areas, particularly for wage earners, women, and poor 
producer groups with the potential to engage in a higher level of commercial activity. These 
developments will be a consequence of addressing the market gaps and failures in selected 
subsectors, and strengthening the competitive position of the MSEs operating within those 
subsectors. These measures are expected to increase the value added in the products sold and 
improve commercial linkages between rural MSEs and the larger urban businesses. Each rural 
industry  has  a  large  number  of  MSEs,  many  of  which  are  in  households.  As  the  Project

develops beyond the TA loan period, it is expected that the know-how developed by the pilot 
initiatives will be transferred to a wider group of rural enterprises. Indirect benefits will arise from 
the strengthening of rural knowledge and human capital, and a reduction in the incentives for 
rural–urban migration. 
 
57.  It is expected that the TA loan’s outputs will result in measurable financial and economic 
benefits for the targeted enterprises and industries. Overall, the TA loan is a catalyst and the full 
economic impact will arise through multiplier effects on the target industries, communities and 
groups. Because of the importance of the multiplier for the achievement of project goals, the 
linkages between the direct activities of the TA loan and the wider rural economy must be 
considered in plans for REMC to continue beyond the TA loan. The TA loan is considered as a 
first step in a longer program that will refine the approaches to rural enterprise modernization 
and extend these approaches to a wider rural base (Supplementary Appendix D). 
  
B.  Environmental and Social Impacts 
 
58.  The  TA  loan  is  classified  as  category  C  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Environmental 
Assessment Guidelines. The focus is on sector analysis and the creation of an institutional 
framework for facilitating rural nonfarm development, and therefore the TA loan will not entail 
involuntary resettlement or have adverse impact on indigenous peoples or the environment 
(Appendix  10).  In  addition,  no  adverse  environmental  impact  is  expected  from  the  pilot 
initiatives. As a check on environmental concerns, and for enhanced environmental awareness 
among rural enterprises, consultants will prepare guidelines and provide training in social and 
environmental screening during the preparation of subsector plans and interventions, including 
the pilot projects. Periodic monitoring by poverty, gender, and environmental consultants will 
ensure that the TA loan’s interventions are socially and environmentally sound. 
 
59.  The TA loan will have positive social impact through increased rural employment and 
household  incomes.  A  systemic  attempt  will  be  made  to  reach  rural  women.  Women  will 
participate actively in the surveys and analyses, and women-managed enterprises will receive 
specialized technical and managerial support. 
 
C.  Risks 
 
60.  The project design makes a number of assumptions with associated risks. It is assumed 
that the Government remains strongly committed to ensuring enhanced market opportunities 
and competitiveness of rural enterprises, especially for those groups that now lack access to 
markets.  The  present  Government  has  demonstrated  strong  ownership  and  commitment 
through a focus on addressing constraints on market access in the rural areas. It is recognized 
that the project design will require a knowledge-intensive approach, with a high degree of 
responsiveness to emerging market opportunities. In addition, there is a need to work with a 
number of institutions both within and outside government. Extensive consultations with all 
stakeholders, including the private sector, and high-level government support if not realized can 
cause delays and may limit the understanding and development of appropriate institutional 
processes  required  to  support  the  competitiveness  of  rural  enterprises.  These  risks  are 
addressed through the creation of a high-level steering committee with adequate representation 
from the government and private sector. In addition, the Project provides flexibility in engaging 
the private sector and other stakeholders in all undertakings, and on-time availability of a range 
of consultants with demonstrated technical knowledge and international experience to analyze 
subsectors and design initiatives responsive to market opportunities in the rural areas. The need 
to stimulate improvements in the design and quality of products and to ensure compliance by 
the  rural  enterprises  with  labor  laws  and  other  regulations  is  addressed  through  a

19
comprehensive  subsector  analysis  followed  by  carefully  designed  pilot  interventions  with 
appropriate social safeguards and processes and private sector linkages. The results of the 
subsector analysis and pilot projects will, in turn, form the basis for the business plan for an 
institution  to  support  the  development  of  business  opportunities  for  rural  entrepreneurs, 
especially those who exhibit substantial business potential but have no access to the required 
resources, knowledge, and support. The proposed sequencing of implementation will help in 
preparing relevant area- and product-specific strategies for promoting business development 
and in minimizing the risks associated with setting up an institution that may otherwise fail to be 
socially responsive, sustainable, and relevant to the needs of the underserved and new small 
rural entrepreneurs. 
 
V.  ASSURANCES 
A.  Specific Assurances 
 
61.  The  Government  has  given  the  following  assurances,  in  addition  to  the  standard 
assurances, which will be incorporated in the legal documents: 
 
(i)  The Government will ensure that adequate counterpart funds are made available 
for the implementation of the TA loan. 
(ii)  The Government will provide adequate office space for the TA loan. 
(iii)  The Government will ensure that the facilities provided under the TA loan are 
operated and maintained appropriately and adequate budget will be provided for 
this purpose. 
(iv)  The Government will ensure that all the interventions/investments meet, to the 
satisfaction  of  ADB,  the  agreed  selection  criteria  and  implementation 
arrangements and that all interventions are, to the satisfaction of ADB, properly 
controlled and monitored. 
(v)  The Government will ensure compliance with all applicable labor laws, including 
the prohibition of child labor, and equal pay for men and women for work of equal 
value for activities under this TA loan. Compliance with these provisions will be 
strictly monitored during the TA loan’s implementation.  
(vi)  Within 1 month of loan effectiveness, recruitment of the team leader for MDP will 
be completed in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for the Use of Consultants. 
Detailed  terms  of  reference,  selection  criteria,  and  recommendations  on  the 
selection of the candidate together with the draft contract will be submitted for 
ADB’s approval. 
(vii)  Within 1 month of loan effectiveness, the Government will designate an officer of 
the level of a joint secretary at MoIPSI for the overall coordination of the TA loan.  
(viii)  Within 18 months of loan effectiveness, the Government will submit to ADB the 
feasibility study on the establishment of REMC; and subject to its feasibility being 
approved by ADB, within 24 months of loan effectiveness the Government will 
ensure that (a) REMC is incorporated as a not-for-profit company under Section 
42 of the Companies Ordinance 1984; (b) the board of directors of REMC will 
have at least nine members with at least six from the private sector, including two 
women; (c) immediately following incorporation, the board of directors approves  
an  annual  business  plan,  standard  operating  procedures,  conflict-of-interest 
rules, and code of conduct for staff and directors. 
(ix)  The Government will ensure that REMC, immediately following its incorporation, 
will enter into a project agreement with ADB setting out its responsibilities.

(x)  Within 3 months of loan effectiveness, the Government will ensure that a first-
year work plan for the TA loan will be prepared and submitted for ADB approval. 
(xi)  The Government will ensure that the Project will not cause any land acquisition, 
resettlement,  or  limits  on  access  to  land.  Furthermore,  the  Government  will 
ensure that affected indigenous peoples will have opportunities to participate in 
and benefit equitably from the Project. The Government will also ensure that the 
Project will not cause any negative environmental impact.

63.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of

including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft Loan and Project Agreements presented to the

RURAL NONFARM ENTERPRISE PROMOTION IN PAKISTAN AND ASIA 
 
1.  Rural nonfarm growth has been most rapid in countries possessing a vibrant agriculture 
and a rapidly growing urban-industrial sector, as well as the requisite managerial and labor 
skills, ready markets for inputs and outputs (including financing), and good infrastructure. Public 
provision of infrastructure—roads, power, and telecommunications—will obviously facilitate rural 
nonfarm dynamism. Rural nonfarm production has mostly comprised non-tradables produced by 
households and microenterprises (e.g., food processing, housing, retail trade, and services). In 
a few East Asian countries—People’s Republic of China (PRC), Republic of Korea, Japan, and 
Taipei,China—rural  industrialization  has  extended  to  larger-scale,  often  export-oriented, 
production of goods such as textiles and metal products. The central feature of Asia’s rural 
nonfarm growth is that it has been led almost entirely by the market and the private sector. State 
efforts to promote rural industrialization directly have generally not succeeded on a broad scale 
(the People’s Republic of China’s township and village enterprises are the primary exception), 
despite the appeal of arguments for enhancing efficient employment creation, alleviating rural 
poverty,  reducing  rural-to-urban  migration,  and  containing  the  external  costs  of  excessive 
urbanization.  
 
A.  Insights from Donor-Supported Small Business Promotion Projects 
 
2.  After  several  years  of  efforts  to  build  a  consensus  on  principles  for  selecting  and 
supporting intermediaries in micro- and small enterprises in finance, around the mid-1990s, the 
Committee  of  Donor  Agencies  for  Small  Enterprise  Development1 turned  its  attention  to 
business development services (BDS)—the wide array of nonfinancial services that enable 
businesses to grow and develop. Motivating the search for a new paradigm for BDS was the 
recognition that traditional interventions have failed to provide good-quality, affordable BDS to a 
large proportion of small enterprises. There was consensus that publicly funded services have 
not achieved their objectives, since programs had had low impact, had limited outreach and cost 
efficiencies, and were not sustainable since service provision ended when program activities 
ended. 
 
3.  Therefore, at its annual meeting in 1995, the donor committee decided to focus on BDS 
for small enterprises, with the objective of identifying and documenting best practices in this 
area. Building on this work, between 1998 and 2000 a series of international and regional 
conferences were organized under the auspices of the donor committee. The BDS working 
group prepared a draft document with guiding principles based on the papers and discussions 
from these conferences. The draft served as the basis for discussion and for the emerging 
consensus  on  principles  for  donor  interventions  in  BDS.  The  “BDS  market  development 
paradigm” grew out of a shred conviction within the donor community that achieving economic 
and social goals was possible only by relying on private sector actors to provide a diverse array 
of  services.  Relying  on  the  private  sector  to  achieve  greater  outreach  demanded  better 
understanding of how BDS providers could be financially self-sustaining or even profitable.

5.  Working Through Community Organizations. Experience gained in the early 1980s 
indicated that though the community organizations were effective in initiating and managing 
public  projects,  the  success  of  a  business  project  rested  on  individual  profit  motivations, 
requiring the skill and creativity of individual entrepreneurs rather than community groups, 
particularly  since  not  all  members  of  a  group  would  have  the  inclination  or  the  drive  for 
business. Issues of mistrust, and questions regarding profit allocations commensurate with the 
time and hard work put in by different group members, further confirmed the nonviability of the 
community organization for commercial activities. The marketing of fresh fruits and vegetables 
through village organizations had its demonstration and awareness-raising effects; nonetheless, 
the business momentum was picking up more outside the community organizations rather than 
within. Additionally, the initial collectivist efforts were steered not by what would sell in the 
market but what could be grown in the northern regions, i.e., they were supply- rather than 
demand-driven. The experience during this phase shattered the belief that the only issue was 
marketing, highlighting the complexities of marketing, the significance of consumer demand, 
competition, and the synchronization of the production and marketing operations to compete 
favorably. 
 
6.  Supporting  Individual  Entrepreneurs.  Subsequently,  AKRSP  shifted  its  focus  to 
supporting individual entrepreneurs through a variety of capacity-building measures and equity 
contributions.  Businesses  in  new  areas  were  established  and  existing  ones  strengthened. 
Nonetheless, the cost of working directly with individual entrepreneurs was very high, and only a 
limited number of entrepreneurs could be reached. Moreover, such direct support for small 
businesspeople  diluted  their  own  stakes  in  the  business,  created  dependency  on  external 
assistance,  and  raised  issues  about  the  sustainability  of  the  momentum  created  within  a 
business once support was withdrawn. Most of all, concern about displacing private sector 
providers of services and creating market distortions also arose.  
 
7.  Creating and Working with Cooperatives. Driven by limited impact and cost-efficiency 
issues and in its efforts to multiply job and income-earning opportunities, AKRSP also tried to 
establish cooperatives with a range of shareholders. These cooperatives remained dependent 
on AKRSP for their day-to-day operational management because of low literacy levels and the 
limited capacity of the managers to work independently. From this experience, AKRSP learned 
three lessons, which influenced its decision to establish its wholly owned businesses. First, 
businesses needed to be established with well-researched profitability prospects. Second, they 
needed to be established as business entities distinct from AKRSP with their own financial

management and accounting systems. And third, the job of managing a large business was 
complex  and  too  specialized  to  be  managed  by  largely  illiterate  poor  farmers,  whose 
commercial  exposure  was  limited.  Subsequently,  criteria  for  establishing  wholly  owned 
businesses were established, not to open the doors to private sector investment but rather to 
make AKRSP more cautious in its choice of investments. 
 
8.  Experience of Wholly Owned Businesses. AKRSP’s direct interventions in the market 
were  rationalized  by  the  absence  of  business  capacity  and  resources  within  the  northern 
regions to take on such ventures and the livelihood opportunities that these projects promised. 
Following a tight process of screening, more business ideas were rejected than accepted at 
AKRSP. Starting in the late 1990s, with cost-free donor funds and limited business experience, 
AKRSP  established  its  wholly  owned  businesses  in  four  subsectors  in  which the  northern 
regions were considered to have a competitive advantage (dry-fruit processing, woolen fabric 
patti/shu marketing, vegetable seed production and marketing, and coal mining). AKRSP had 
the advantage of access to cost-free donor funds. The long-term objective was to make these 
projects profitable and privatize them. 
 
2.  Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) 
 
9.  In 1997 SDC assisted the Karakorum Area Development Organization based in Hunza 
(Northern  Areas  of  Pakistan)  in  establishing  the  Threadnet  Project  (TP)  to  enhance  poor 
women’s income-earning opportunities. Design, raw material purchase, product development, 
and marketing are centralized functions performed by TP. Women are contracted to work either 
at home or at the work centers of TP to produce a variety of hand-embroidered products such 
as pouches, key chains, handbags, and belts. The embroidery skills of more than 300 women 
have been polished and they are earning about PRs1,500 to PRs2,500 per month (on a piece-
rate basis). The projects sell mainly among visiting tourists in the northern regions of Pakistan, 
though efforts have also been made to tap selective stores down-country. The project lacks in-
house business and design expertise and is heavily dependent on donor funding. The prospects 
of the project becoming a financially sustainable business are suspect. SDC is currently in the 
process of deciding how best to disengage itself from the project as part of its exit strategy from 
the Northern Areas. Had attention to an exit route been paid right from the start, perhaps the 
design of the project would have augured better for its sustainability.  
 
10.  Other initiatives of the SDC in the Northern Areas include an apricot oil extraction and 
marketing business and green-wood furniture making. Both projects have been set up to spur 
interest among the risk-averse local people by demonstrating to them the business potential of 
these two sectors. Nonetheless, it is still too early to comment on the impact of these projects, 
as they were initiated very recently. 
 
C.  Enterprise Development Experience in Other Rural Areas 
 
11.  Traditionally, targeted and singularly focused efforts to safeguard the economic interests 
of the rural and peri-urban poor have been pursued by nongovernment organizations (NGOs) 
and social development programs since they work directly with the poor to alleviate poverty. 
Even though poverty is a complex phenomenon with many causes and no single route to its 
amelioration, most agencies accept the more non-controversial and generally held belief that 
poverty is about absence of economic opportunities and the capacity to avail oneself of those 
that do exist. Hence, it is understandable when development organizations working with the 
poor design interventions that focus on economic aspects of poverty or when public initiatives 
focus on the same.

Appendix 4          37 
12.  Concerted programs for integrating the poor in mainstream commercial activities can be 
broadly  categorized  into  financial  (in  Pakistan  the  focus  is  mainly  on  micro-credit)  and 
nonfinancial BDS, though nonfinancial services also frequently come packaged with micro-
credit. It is important to highlight the fact that while micro-credit operations and products can be 
standardized  for  given  target  groups  and  geographic  locations,  nonfinancial  services  are 
different, and standardizing them would be contrary to their objective of being demand-driven 
and responsive to market realities. This makes the design, implementation, and monitoring of 
nonfinancial service programs more challenging and demanding.  
 
13.  While holistic social rural development through community group mobilization and the 
building of self-help capacity has a rich and encouraging history in Pakistan, the record of 
nonfinancial  service  programs  to  enhance  income-earning  and  job  opportunities  for  the 
marginalized  poor  is  mixed,  debatable,  and  not  as  clear  in  its  accomplishments.  Various 
programmatic designs have been tried, but plaguing nonfinancial service programs is a supply-
led, direct-service-delivery, subsidies-oriented approach that is constrained in its outreach, not 
sustainable over the long run, cost-inefficient, and therefore also limited in impact and not 
replicable. 
 
14.  Representative popular NGO models for delivering nonfinancial BDS to the poor and 
marginalized communities in down-country Pakistan are discussed below. 
 
1.  Supporting  the  Production  and  Marketing  of  Handicrafts  and 
Circumventing the Problems Caused by the “Evil Middle Man”  
 
15.  For  access  to  commercial  markets  for  their  products,  particularly  embroideries  and 
handicrafts  produced  by  women,  communities  living  in  remote  areas  depend  on 
middlemen/women. The farther the distance from commercial markets, the higher the service 
charge or commission of the agent. In addition, the more dispersed the producers, the less the 
likelihood of their collectively associating to gain more negotiating leverage. Women’s limited 
mobility in the rural areas is a major constraint on their active engagement in the commercial 
arena. 
 
16.  In their efforts to circumvent the high commission charges to poor communities, some 
NGOs have set up working units or their own agents within the rural areas, which serve as 
points where work is contracted out to women and where delivery of final products is taken. To 
find good markets for women’s handicrafts and embroideries, the NGOs also provide women 
with design and product manufacturing assistance and access to raw materials. In this respect, 
the NGO serves as a business contracting out work to piece-rate workers and selling it in the 
market. Though these initiatives address the design and marketing needs of the rural and peri-
urban women, the NGOs do not function as  profitable, and hence sustainable, ventures as their 
business  operations  are  heavily  subsidized  and  dependent  on  donor  grants,  with  limited 
prospects  of  attaining  financial  sustainability  in  the  future.  Thus,  their  activities  can  be 
categorized as noble welfare activities but not as a business model that can be replicated. 
Illustrative  examples  are  the  Threadnet  Project  of  the  Karakorum  Area  Development 
Organization, and Hawwa Associates and Sungi Foundation’s women’s hand-embroidery and 
handicrafts outlets in Islamabad.  
 
2.  Vocational Training for Employment 
 
17.  The  rural support  programs  (most  notably  the  National Rural  Support  Programme), 
through their affiliate capacity-building organizations, provide a range of vocational training

38          Appendix 4 
programs in the farm and nonfarm areas (in welding, cooking, tailoring, driving, auto-mechanic, 
stitching,  knitting,  and  other  skills)  to  improve  the  job  prospects  of  the  poor.  Community 
organizations within a given area identify the prospective trainees, and final selection is made 
by the rural support program through a rigorous process to determine the seriousness of the 
potential trainee and his/her economic status. Training is conducted through the vocational 
training institutes of the Government, whose service delivery capacity has been strengthened 
and training programs redesigned to meet market job requirements. Since the aim is to target 
the poorest of the poor or the jobless, training is highly subsidized and only a token fee is 
charged. For women, training is conducted within the community. Thousands of people in 79 out 
of Pakistan’s 120 districts have been trained over the last few years. Through random sampling, 
training utilization is checked. Overall, it appears that this program is enabling people to get 
semiskilled and skilled jobs.  
 
3.  Private Business Subcontracting Model: Providing Embedded Services on 
a Sustainable Basis 
 
18.  Perhaps the most viable mechanisms through which home-based and small businesses 
are acquiring BDS in a sustainable fashion are in the shape of embedded services (i.e., services 
that come packaged with commercial transactions between businesses). For example, many 
private women-owned businesses have sprung up around areas where there is a prevalence of 
hand-embroidery skill—almost across Pakistan’s rural and selected peri-urban areas. Typically, 
design, purchase of raw materials, cutting and stitching, and the final sale of the garments are 
centralized functions performed at the factory/premises of the entrepreneur. Poor women skilled 
in embroidery are contracted by the entrepreneurs on a piece-rate basis and provided designs, 
raw materials, and some coaching in new embroidery techniques and skills. The women either 
take the work home and complete it as and when their home responsibilities permit, or work for 
fixed hours at the premises of the entrepreneur. By linking up with business-savvy private 
entrepreneurs,  rural  women  are  able  to  have  an  assured  income  and  markets  and  can 
overcome limitations in market access, information about consumer preferences, and design. 
 
19.  Businesses  targeting  high-end  consumers  are  more  quality-conscious  and  therefore 
willing to invest more in building the capacities of the small businesses that they subcontract to, 
so that the latter remain loyal to them and do not start supplying to competition, as is bound to 
happen inevitably. A small business that has gained important technology, design, and market 
access  by  working  with  larger  businesses  is  Millat  Tractors  Limited.  Millat  claims  to  have 
developed the entire vehicle parts industry in Pakistan by working with home-based workshop 
owners  and  upgrading  their  capacities,  in  addition  to  working  with  large  parts  suppliers. 
Likewise, the income levels of the tobacco-leaf-growing farmers in the North-West Frontier 
Province have improved substantially through their work with Pakistan Tobacco Limited and 
Lakson Tobacco Limited.  
 
D.  Selected International Experience 
 
20.  Several successful models of this approach in the region have had a major impact on 
the rural economy. These include the “One Tambon–One Product” Program (OTOP) and the 
Thai Business Initiative in Rural Development (TBIRD) Program (undertaken by an NGO) in 
Thailand. The Government of Pakistan views the OTOP model as having the potential to be a 
catalyst for rural modernization in Pakistan. Thailand also has its National Support Services 
Program, which has been implemented for 4 years by the Bank of Agriculture and Agricultural 
Cooperatives (BAAC) with the European Union as the international partner. In the Philippines 
the Growth with Equity in Mindanao Program has similarities in approach with the concept of

Appendix 4          39 
“economically  just  development,”  which  has  attracted  the  interest  of  the  Government  of 
Pakistan.  
 
21.  OTOP has focused on various rural products including textiles, ceramics, handcrafted 
paper, fruits and vegetables, and leather goods. Design and technology assistance (for raw 
materials,  product  identification,  packaging,  transport,  and  finance)  is  supported  by  a 
sophisticated  market  information  system.  Partly  through  participation  in  product/trade  fairs, 
OTOP tries to connect craft manufacturers with a global market that rewards a high level of craft 
skill and encourages self-reliance and the human development of village folk. However, there 
are aspects of the OTOP program that are very specific to its origins and to Thailand. OTOP 
was based on a program started in Oita Province in Japan. The purpose of this project was to 
improve on locally available products and produce goods acceptable to the international market. 
This  program  inspired  the  Thai  Government  to  adopt  a  similar  approach.  “One  Tambon 
(Village)” was included in the title to emphasize the twin ideas of equality (the program is spread 
across  the  village  economy)  and  comparative  advantage.  The  Japan  External  Trade 
Organization  (JETRO)  launched  a  1-year  program  to  support  the  Thai  Government  from 
January to December 2002. 
 
22.  From  an  institutional  point  of  view,  OTOP  involves  many  related  ministries  and 
departments of the Thai Government. It is important to understand that the system of local 
government in Thailand is strong. Local government coverage is wide and a number of powers 
are decentralized especially to the province. Thailand has what is termed a “CEO” style of 
provincial  government,  whereby  provincial  governors  are  encouraged  to  look  upon  their 
province as a business and to maximize its “profits.” This approach to local government fits well 
with  OTOP.  Given  this  structure,  there  has  been  no  need  to  develop  a  distinct  OTOP 
corporation. 
 
23.  OTOP can draw on technical departments and on financial institutions for technical 
assistance. In the Thai context, local skill levels are often quite high (one reason why the 
program was able to select a “One Product” approach is that the ethnic/cultural base of the Thai 
normally allows for a high degree of specialization by a given community). OTOP has received 
considerable support from the financial sector. The support comes from such institutions as the 
Village Fund, the People’s Bank Program, and the Small and Medium Enterprise Development 
Bank. The provision of micro-credit has been an exceptionally important aspect of OTOP. 
 
24.  Key to understanding the implementation of OTOP is the link between the program and 
Japan. JETRO saw that rural craft manufacturers in Thailand had already achieved a high 
degree of skill and considerable product diversity. This had been encouraged for years, e.g., by 
the Royal Project of His Majesty the King. There was already a base of skills and products that 
would appeal to the Japanese consumer. 
 
25.  OTOP has therefore focused on the Japanese market (and to a degree on the tourists 
visiting Thailand). JETRO provided the services of Japanese design experts and other technical 
assistance  to  upgrade  selected  products  specifically  for  Japan.  OTOP  emphasizes 
environmentally  friendly,  handmade,  and  high-quality  products,  which  are  not  necessarily 
cheap. In no sense is OTOP “poverty relief”; it seeks to encourage people to aspire to a much 
higher standard of living. 
 
26.  The country context of OTOP is quite different from that of Pakistan. OTOP built on the 
tradition of village specialization in products and the existing high level of skill. This situation is 
not present in Pakistan. Secondly, in contrast to Pakistan, the local government system in

Thailand  is  well  developed  with  provincial  heads  managing  their  constituencies  with 
considerable entrepreneurial autonomy. Thirdly, and most important, OTOP started off with an 
edge in that there was a keen market for its products. Japanese investors were interested in 
what was being produced in Thailand and willing to invest in it. Lastly, OTOP is a government 
initiative operated without cost to the enterprise. Other international experiences like the TBIRD 
project in Thailand have more relevance for Pakistan. 
 
E.  Thailand Business Initiative in Rural Development  
 
27.  On the premise that NGOs and villagers do not have the required business acumen, the 
TBIRD project aims to link the informal rural sectors and formal businesses. The Population and 
Development Association, which started the project, leveraged its success in family planning 
and rural development to engage multinationals to “adopt” villages and develop sustainable 
business projects. Companies sponsor TBIRD projects by contributing 5% of their director’s 
fees and 5% of the director’s bonus to a fund for rural development. Some companies provide 
more. Other companies provide technical assistance, for instance by providing their workers 
paid leave to go to the project village and help directly in establishing a manufacturing line. The 
program has had considerable success working with the Bata shoe company. About 4 million 
pairs of shoes are now made in northeastern Thai villages (the poorest part of the country). Nike 
and Dr Scholl are also involved in the program.  
 
F.  National Support Services Program (NSSP), Thailand 
 
28.  NSSP began in 2001, in the aftermath of the financial crisis of 1997, and ended in 
February  2005.  Its  objective  was  to  respond  to  the  needs  of  smaller  and  poorer  Thai 
communities to have a wider range of high-quality financial services. Another objective was to 
offer villagers support in dealing with people returning to the rural areas from the cities as a 
result of the financial crisis. The project involved thousands of villagers and staff from BAAC, 
which  was  the  executing  agency.  There  were  two  main  components:  a  microfinance 
development program, and a community enterprise development program financed through a 
revolving fund by the European Union for a total grant of €15 million.  
 
29.  The project was able to reach 360 villages or community enterprise groups with 36,000 
villagers qualifying for training. Males and females were almost equally balanced in receiving 
support. Activities were concentrated in three provinces (Thailand has over 70 provinces), which 
were considered pilot areas. NSSP developed a number of key tools designed to provide skills 
and  assist  in  creating  strong  and  disciplined  microfinance  intermediaries  and  community 
enterprise groups. These tools included aspects of accounting, management, and marketing 
designed to qualify the groups for credit from BAAC.  
 
30.  Outreach has been a major factor in the success of the NSSP. BAAC has nationwide 
coverage down to the subdistrict level, with representatives in almost every community. These 
persons also received training under the project while providing critical local knowledge to the 
project staff at national level. An important lesson learned was that the project had to target 
groups that had already started in business (not necessarily the poorest of the poor) and that 
had an established network of community and business relationships. Social as well as physical 
collateral was found to be an indicator of debt performance.

that as many people as possible, including members of cultural and religious minorities, benefit

to  producer  groups  and  other  organizations.  It  works  with  producers’  associations  and

32.  The principal activities of GEM to promote growth are: (i) business support organization

H.  Charoen Pokphand 
 
33.  Technology  transfer  can  also  be  achieved  by  the  private  sector  through  contract 
production.  A  well-known  example  of  technology  and  business  links  between  large-scale 
agribusiness and small farmers was pioneered in Thailand by Charoen Pokphand (CP), a 
company that later became a large conglomerate, extending its reach to other Asian countries. 
CP brought in a poultry hybrid and set up a large automated feed mill, which remains the core of 
its operations. The arrangements between the farmers and CP range from a guaranteed price 
contract to a guaranteed wage contract. The sheds in which the chickens are raised are owned 
and operated by the farmers, although their construction may be financed with loans from the 
contracting company. With a guaranteed price contract, prices of inputs and output are fixed in 
advance, with the firm bearing all the price risk, while farmers bear the production risk. CP’s 
extension  services  are  remarkable  in  intensity  and  quality.  The  company’s  extension  staff 
makes regular visits to provide technical information, check the animals’ health, and ensure that 
the farmers follow the company’s regulations. Many farmers graduate to fully independent 
status as contractors, although links to CP are usually maintained through purchase of the 
company’s feed. Poultry raising in Thailand has grown within two decades into a major export 
industry. 
 
34.  Private contract farming could be extended to nonfarm rural enterprises, but may have 
only a limited role to play. Where contract farming has been most successful, there is usually a 
relatively rigid package of technical inputs and a high ratio of purchased inputs in total costs. In 
addition, because of economies of scale, companies like CP tend to work with the larger farms 
and  to  push  small  farmers  into  undertaking  larger  operations.  The  main  lesson  that  it 
demonstrates is that a very input-intensive agriculture such as poultry raising also requires very 
intensive input from a labor force that is suitably educated (in this case, the extension staff of 
the contracting company and, over time, the contract farmers with their newly acquired skills).

35.  At the other end of the investment scale from CP, Narai Technologies Co. Ltd. (NT) was

approximately 200 km from Bangkok). In 2000, NT sold the business at a profit and transferred

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Pakistan: 
The rural sector of Pakistan plays a critical role in the economic development of the country. Poverty in Pakistan has a 
significant rural dimension. The number of poor people1 in Pakistan rose sharply in rural areas during the 1990s from 
22.1% of the population in 1990 to 35.2% in 1999. By the end of the 1990s the number had increased from 25.2% to 
33% in Punjab, from 24.1% to 26.6% in Sindh, and from 35.5% to 42.6% in the North-West Frontier Province (only in 
Balochistan was there a substantial decline from 38.4% to 22.8%).2 Understanding intraregional poverty is also very 
important (e.g., in Northern Punjab the incidence of poverty is 29.5% whereas in Central Punjab it is 34.8% and in 
Southern Punjab it is 39.7%).  
 
A very important characteristic of rural poverty in Pakistan is that upward of 40% of the labor force depends entirely on 
nonfarm activities. In the 1990s the growth of nonfarm activities was severely affected by low economic growth, a 
decline in public sector spending, and lower worker remittances from the Middle East due to the scaling down of the 
construction boom. 
 
Traditional rural development programs are most unlikely to improve the livelihoods of this group of nonagricultural 
laborers domiciled in the rural areas. It is to this group of people, which includes some of the poorest and most 
vulnerable groups, that the Project is targeted. The emphasis in the Project is one of rural modernization, not rural 
development. It takes a different approach: the identification of new technologies and ideas (e.g., for design and 
marketing) and their transfer to rural communities to facilitate institutional processes required to support the transfer of 
competitive approaches to industrial and market activities. The focus is on fostering rural businesses and associations 
and transferring modern commercial practices, together with a strong emphasis on human and management (“soft 
asset”) development. It is based on a trajectory of development that has facilitated economic and social development 
in other developing member countries, especially the countries of East and Southeast Asia. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
Economic determinants of poverty include decline in public sector investment and fiscal policy, limited participation of 
women in the remunerated labor force, inflation, and lack of access to markets and services in the rural areas. Social 
determinants include the highly unequal distribution of land; the hierarchical, almost semifeudal, structure of parts of 
rural society; the low levels of human development; and gender inequalities.  
The Government of Pakistan has facilitated a wide range of responses to poverty including governance reforms, 
ongoing public works programs, a microfinance program, and a variety of social protection programs. The Project has 
a focus on micro- and small enterprises (MSEs), one of the four sectors identified in the Poverty Reduction Strategy 
Paper for reducing poverty in Pakistan. Civil society groups including nongovernment organizations (NGOs) and the 
private sector are also involved in a range of activities to alleviate or reduce poverty.
